page.title: 06Housing in Saxilby Area
page.content: Saxilby has been infilled in the last 15 years and development extended westwards. Houses of all periods are brickbuilt with slate or pantile roofs . The proportion of bungalows is high. There are 150 council dwellings plus Oaklands, 14 flats for the elderly with a warden. Two large houses have been converted into private residential homes. Saxilby's older houses are Victorian or Edwardian with a few exceptions. 76 High Street is a part 16th century timber frame house now restored and the Manor House is part 16th century. An annual award is made for the most improved property and has included the old school and September Cottage. A few cottages and farmhouses lie to the west of Saxilby. Broxholme's buildings are well spaced and attractive. 3 are listed, the oldest is a 17th century cottage.
